The drinks were fantastic.  We started with some hot seasonal punch, followed up by a glass of their 'on-tap' Syrah, and then a flight of their mead.  The service was excellent as well.  My only complaint would be that the restaurant is fairly small, so some of the tables are placed fairly close together.  As a result, I found myself being forced to listen to the conversation of the table next to me.  This became less and less annoying as alcohol consumption continued.

Wow! This was a recommended joint and boy I was happy that I gave it a try. Outstanding service and food with a creative flare in both their drinks and entrees. 

While it may be a bit pricier than other restaurants in the area, you get what you pay for. 

I highly recommend going in hungry since you will need to try their cheese curds for an app and their chocolate chip cookies for dessert

What a great meal. At first the menu seems a little odd. But soon I found two appetizers that looked good: the beets and goat cheese salad and the baked butternut squash. But the best was the rainbow trout with celery and green apple and some root vegetable purer. My husband lived the warm spiced white wine which was lively. The warm cranberry tart  ala mode was delicious too!

Graze had always been good about dogs. Yesterday, we were seated, with dogs, at the edge of the patio (dogs were actually off the patio). We were approached by a manager who stated that they recently changed their policy due to "staff with allergies" and "risks". Bummer guys. Lots of other spots (DLUX, Merchant, etc) still totally okay with dogs outside. 

Scratch this one off the list of Madison's dog friendly establishments.

The only good thing about this place is the beer. But seriously, the cheese curds and heirloom tomato salad were good but the entrees were terrible. The lamb was disgusting and the market price steak was a 6 oz. cut of Bavettes with terrible potatoes and greens for $30. C'mon chef Tony I was expecting a lot better.

I ordered burger with soup, they were great.
I like the atmosphere in the restaurant with beautiful view of capitol.
I enjoyed having lunch here.

Real good food.

Started with the deviled eggs. Little too much mustard for my liking, but deviled eggs are a personal thing.

Me and two friends orders the burger (dairy free) on cibatta bread, fish and chips (a Friday special) that were amazing, and the chicken and waffles... damn good.

Great prices for the quality of food.

It's a tale of very good, good and ugly for me. So wanted to love it but alas only a three. 
Very good as many on Yelp have suggested was the Korean bowl with pork. Just enough spice to satisfy without overwhelming. Thoroughly enjoyed (5 for this one). 
Very good was the selection of cheese and the two that we selected. Perfect and delicious. 
Good was the deviled eggs. Had a nice siracci mayo. We both enjoyed this!
Now unfortunately the bad. Heard great things about the burgers. Ordered one and it was RAW. Now the waitress never asked how we wanted it but RAW?  Standard is medium. Picky folks like my wife is medium well but ground meat is chock full of bacteria. When you grind meat the outsides and insides mix so simply searing the newly formed outside doesn't kill the former outside that's now in. Epic fail for high end place. Asked waitress to cook more and all she said was "how do you want it cooked" and not so sorry to serve you raw ground beef. Kinda bummed me out. Wanted to give a four star but if I get ill tonight may downgrade to two.

Six words: Ambiance Abound and Close to Downtown

In addition to their fantastic space, they have very tasty, vegetarian friendly dishes. A menu of deviled eggs, grilled cheeses and beat burgers sounds like the recipe for a direct passage to Hell. Yet their wine and beer selection will make you feel like you are still in Heaven. At least for a little while.

Graze is my favorite spot in Madison. The floor-to-ceiling windows give a gorgeous view of the Capitol Square, and the interior decor is lovely. The service staff is polite and well-versed in the menu options. But enough about the ambiance. The food is why we're all here.

The FOOD. It is so good. I had the bibimbap - it is a must-have when you come here. It is hearty and filling - just delightful.

The fries are delicious. Their burgers are great. The beer selection is fantastic. 

As a former-Wisconsinite, I'm partial to Madison. Every time I visit the state, Madison is my first stop, and Graze is my first choice for dining.

What a wonderful surprise! After rethinking our reservation to l'etoile next door (fancy French restaurant next door) because we wanted something more low key, we wandered into graze and could not have been happier. First off, their drink menu is full of interesting and unique drinks made with seasonal ingredients. Second, all their food showcases the freshness of the local farms that Graze sources it's ingredients from. Every bite we had was delicious starting with the mixed greens salad (a yelper favorite), to the pickled veggies plate to the smash burger and ratatouille. We capped things off with the blueberry pie and buttermilk ice cream.

One of the best meals I've had in a long time! Just wish they had this restaurant in Chicago where we live.

While Graze tends to have some overpriced and inconsistent dishes, it is a beautiful brunch spot and has some really delicious options, if you order correctly. 

Try the Magic Coffee. It will not disappoint. Perfect on a hot day after the Farmer's Market.

Also, their cheese curds are one of my favorites in Madison. Get them!

Other than that, they have a yummy Belgian Waffle with DC cherries, if you see it in-season on the menu.

In general, Graze can sometimes miss the mark on its more explorative and imaginative dishes, so it takes a couple visits to figure out what's good. But once you do, it's a really lovely place to take the family for brunch or lunch.

Very very nice setting. Pastries in the morning are fantastic. 

However, recently I went later in the evening I saw that there are problems. First, the menu is interesting, but a little odd. It's good to experiment and explore, but in this case, the menu is more bizarre than tempting. 

But the real problem was the service. It was beyond poor -- it was incompetent. Our waiter took our order (and got confused with some simple substitutions we asked about) and brought one of us a little sample of one of the beers we were curious about. Then he disappeared. No follow-up on the beer -- which we wanted to order -- no "is everything all right?" Finally, some other waitress brought the food, and we asked *her* to bring the beer. She was cheerful, and approved of our choice. But we never saw her, or the beer, either. Finally, in exasperation, we flagged someone down and ordered the beer *again*, and this time we got it (far into our meal). And then we were abandoned again. We finished, and wanted to pay. And waited, and looked, and waited. And again, we had to flag some other waiter down in order to pay. The whole experience was ridiculous.
I come to Graze on the reg. There are always new things to try inspired by different cuisines. This is a Tory Miller kitchen, so the flavors are always on point.

It's everything everyone says about it, and it's a shame it's taken this long for me to try it, but I'm glad I did. In fact, It's so good I'm making Graze my first review after a long stint on the disabled list with stomach problems -- a nightmare for a wannabe foodie like me. 

The beer and drink lists are so vast, you could spend your entire 45-minute wait for a table just deciding what to have; I had an old fashioned well made enough to rival those of Graze's eponymous down-the-block neighbor. 

The menu was less vast, but everything looked so good it took just as long to decide. A pretzel seems so simple, but makes for an incredible appetizer when surrounded by Graze's house made dipping sauces. For dinner, I went for the Graze burger; I've been dreaming about it nightly ever since. 

Enjoy the view, the attractive crowd, the drinks, the apps, the everything. Don't wait as long as I did to come here. Just go.

I have yet to be disappointed by this place and it is always one of the first places that I bring guests when they visit Madison. The full walls of windows makes this place light up during the day and gives you a beautiful view of the Capitol square that makes the whole ambiance of this restaurant quite wonderful. There is quite a bit of seating, but it is spread out enough that it actually feels very spacious with open windows. Additionally, the bar that is the central point of the restaurant is a great addition that makes fantastic drinks year round. I highly recommend having any of the cocktails and definitely the seasonal punch that no matter what season it is, it has never disappointed. 

I have had numerous things on the menu from appetizers to entrees and have yet to find something I didn't like. Although a weird item for a Wisconsin menu, the Bibmbap is a must-have that is packed full of flavor in every bite. You have an option of adding in pork or tofu to it and either way you go you can't go wrong. I have been avidly against tofu for a long time because I often find that it has little flavor and a weird texture, but this tofu is flavored in a spicy sauce that makes it a delicious addition of protein to this meal. They also have a rotating market menu that always has a wide selection of dinner entrees that consistently make deciding on a meal difficult because they are all so enticing. Honestly, in terms of appetizers, you can't go wrong with cheese curds in Wisconsin, but the spinach and artichoke dip accompanied by toasted crostini is a wonderful starter that is perfectly creamy without being too heavy. All in all this is a great spot in Madison that shouldn't be overlooked.

we checked graze out a few weeks ago for a change of pace for brunch. we were seated immediately. our server was really pleasant and attentive. the decor is really cool... lofty and modern but somehow very cozy.

we started with bloodies, of course... and they were a little odd. there is a smoky flavor to the mix which i didn't love (but it didn't stop me from having two).

we each ordered something different. I had the breakfast sandwich with brick cheese, which was good and everything I expected. my boyfriend had the chicken fried steak. (he liked it but he was a bit disappointed with the portion size... I kept reminding him that we weren't at the old fashioned.) my sister-in-law had the croque madame, and, with some prodding, my brother ordered the chicken and waffles. I tried a bite of these dishes and liked both. the chicken and waffles was pretty amazing and I will definitely order this dish next time. 

as if we weren't already stuffed, we shared a chocolate croissant and some coffee cake after our meal. both were good but not amazing. 

all in all, this is a solid place for brunch and we'll definitely be back.
Superior dining, Superior service, Superior ambience and view of the Capital.  Local ingredients and an award winning chef!! Drinks outstanding! Viist, Eat! Enjoy!!  Favorite place in Madison!!!

Came here with two friends spontaneously after visiting the farmer's market today, about 1 pm. It was busy with the end of the farmer's market brunch rush, so we sat at the bar to get a drink and wait for a table. We ended up just ordering and eating there, too. The bartender was very friendly and helpful. Loved the Bloody Mary and the cheese curds. The Eggs Benedict was pretty good. All in all, I felt like the drinks were the highlight of our visit. The atmosphere was wonderful and modern, very nice but not pretentious. I'd visit again, and look forward to trying more drinks, but would lean more toward lunch/dinner options rather than breakfast. Still thinking about those cheese curds though :)

Honestly, I'm not really sure what all the hype is about. I will say, the location is great, and the servers I've encountered have been nothing but friendly and attentive. 

However, the food just isn't that great. First of all, I wish they had more pork-free options on the menu that weren't vegetarian. The first time at Graze, I went with my mom, brother, and sister and we ordered a selection of stuff to share: cheese curds (good, though I slightly prefer those at dlux or merchant), cheese plate (again, decent, but nothing special) and a bibimbap bowl (I guess it was good, I'm a supertaster, so I sometimes like my food a little more bland than most people, but this wasn't even flavorful to me). On the plus side, their lemonade is always delicious. 

All in all, it's pretty mediocre and doesn't live up to its image. I probably won't be back any time soon.

I'm still not impressed by this place. The atmosphere is great and the drinks are strong but the food is just ok :-/ * the drinks are strong at most bars/restaurants in Madison :-)

Pickle board- ok

Pub Burger- almost not edible because it was over cooked....like eating cardboard :-(

Hickory Nut Bourbon-Caramel Pie- absolutely delicious. It's very similar to pecan pie, my favorite.

I'm updating my review and knocking off one star.  My wife and I went to Graze last Saturday night after a hiatus of six months or so, and I was somewhat disappointed.  We called around eight o'clock and asked about the wait and we were told it would be an hour.  I tried to give my name, but they said that I would have to come in to the restaurant.  That was annoying.

We got there about an hour later and were told it would be a forty-five minute wait.  When we were seated, I'm pretty sure we got the worst table in the restaurant-- people bumped into me throughout the meal.  The service was fine, but I wasn't too thrilled to see that the prices had been raised by a few dollars.  You know what's more ridiculous than paying almost $20 for a burger?  Paying over $20 for a burger.

The real kicker was the end of our meal.  After waiting for forty-five minutes and spending over $100, they switched the lights on 15 minutes before closing to let us know to get the hell out.  That was incredibly obnoxious.

I have a huge crush on Graze and I'm not even sure where to start. The gorgeous capital-view glass-encased atmosphere? The incredible fresh local ingredients? The Korean-inspired flare? For now I'll say it's the lavender lemonade because HOLY mother of all things tangy this stuff is amazing. Graze has never disappointed.

PROS: Interesting local-fusion concept, cute interior, decent prices and portions
CONS: ?

Funny walking in, ordering the vegetarian bibimbap, and observing that all the fancily-dressed women from different tables ordered exactly the same thing! BBB IS IN! This spot is hip, cute, packed with a lot of young urbanites and...slightly yuppy?

I thoroughly enjoyed the chef's choice cheese platter appetizer that we ordered, as well as my non-classic Graze-ian bibimbap, which had little crispy cubes of rice -- rather interesting and innovative take on achieving the clay-pot crispy rice feel of traditional Korean bibimbap. I look forward to coming back!

Went here for a late dinner. The restaurant has an amazing selection of local produce. The cheese platter as a starter is great and there is a good set to select from. They have a good selection of fish and meat to choose from for the main dishes. Had the "burger" with fries. The burger has tasty and cooked to specification. The fries were OK but nothing special. They have a great selection of Wisconsin beer. Overall a great meal and I am certainly coming back to try more of their food.

Good food, although slightly pricey for what I got.  Ordered the Impossible burger, as Graze is one of the only 2 places in Madison that offers it.  The burger was the Impossible patty with the Double Cheese Smash Burger topping.  It was good, although the patty was a little flat/smushed, but I'm not sure if that was a result of the burger itself or preparation.  The taste was good but combined with the thin patty and the toppings of the pickles and burger sauce I felt like I was eating a $16 Big Mac.  I think the fries were slightly overdone as well.  It was a solid meal with no glaring errors, but it ended up being pretty pricey with the patty substitution.  However, our waitress was very accommodating and the view of the Captiol building made for a quite nice ambience.  Hopefully I'll be back to try other dishes!

Well, what a delightful brunch spot! We stopped in on a whim while driving through Madison this morning. There were plenty of open tables, which was crazy; this place in Chicago would have a constant hour wait. The space is bright and open, all windows and super high ceilings. I got Nutella-stuffed French toast that was super tasty without being too sweet or too filling. The house lemonade of the day was strawberry rhubarb and it was delicious. I saw that they have a nice selection of local cheeses, meats, and a couple of oysters. They also have wine on tap. I loved that the entire back of the menu was a list of the farms they work with. All in all, just a wonderful birthday brunch. Come to Chicago, OK?

Forgot my poached egg in the noodle bowl for brunch. Luckily I am a forgiving person. Everything else was delicious. My partner in crime had the eggs Benny and ate that shit like no tomorrow. *hi five, graze*

I'm town visiting Wisco with my family!   Easy walk from the Hampton Downtown Inn.  Great atmosphere and view of the Capitol.  Our family was able to taste all of the top dishes.  We had Mac N Cheese with pulled pork for a starter along with a warm hot pretzel. Then, we had fish n chips (haddock) for Good Friday (yes Easter Weekend), Graze Burger, Fish Stew, Bibimbap and Pork Tenderloin.  You think we were finished?   Traveling from SoCal, we dived into their apple pie and cookies and milk.  Ok, now for my take and reviews...great service!  We left very full.  The fish n chips was fried nicely with beer battered.   The Bibimbap has a nice kick. Loved the Graze Burger.  The Pork T was ok.  My kids loved the MNC.  And to finish on a high note - the mile and cookies were the best!  Next time, I would pass on the Apple Pie.  And if one of my kids attends college here, I would come back and do the pork buns and cheese curds.  We highly recommend!

One of our "go-to's" while in Madison. Both the view and food are hard to beat. Located in a glass-sided building on the square so at most of the tables you have the Capital building as a backdrop. It's especially pretty at night. 

Graze is a locally-sourced restaurant meaning that the food is local and the farm/cheese maker, etc. is known by the diner. The menu is small but we have never been disappointed by the selection. We only stop once a year while in town and have noticed that the menu does change but some of our favorites are still available (Kimshi Deviled Eggs). We always start with a cheese plate which you select from a list of 12 various local styles/flavors and is served with toast wedges and preserves. Your server can help with your selection.

The food is seriously good. Both the entrees and starters are unique to Graze and are perfectly prepared. The flavors and textures of whatever we have ordered are complex and seasoned just right. The prices are up there but I don't mind paying for food of this quality. Portion size is just right. From past experience the desserts are awesome but you may not have room if you enjoyed an appetizer. Very good coffee.

Service has always been good but on our last visit not quite as personal. Food delivery is timely. The beer selection isn't great but you're coming here for the food and I'm sure you will agree to something they have.

My only issue this past visit and much of what's keeping my rating from perfect is the lighting. It may have been just our table which was located right next to the window but it was so dark that I had a difficult time seeing my meal and it took away some of my enjoyment of dining. While romantic and offering a better view of the Capital we needed an additional candle. Otherwise the ambience is modern and clean, focusing on the dining experience and not the trappings of what's hanging on the wall.

I wish I could give 4.5 stars as we love this place and will keep coming back. This is one of many nice places to eat downtown but the combination of quality of food and the Capital backdrop is what does it for us.
Their Bibimbap is phenomenal...I've never had any better!  Crispy, fried rice cake, kimchi, carrots and other assorted veggies with egg and spiced meat...it truly doesn't get any better than this.
Great space, food and service from the wait staff was good, but one of the bartender who worked last night is snooty and rude. Not sure I will be spending my $ there anymore.

In town over the weekend looking for a good casual dinner with fresh ingredients. We started with cheese curds because when I'm WI ;-) had the Peterson steak with sweet potato hash. Very good. The fired chicken was also good, but we wish we would've gone for the burger instead. All in all a very good dining experience in terms of the environment, service and food.

Graze is a great restaurant to bring friends, family, coworkers, etc. Milkshakes and burgers are amazing, huge fan of their seasonal berry dish. Can't complain about the bottomless mimosas either :) Definitely a must-go to spot in Madison.

Went to groomsmen brunch here the day of the wedding and have to say I was impressed. I was extremely hungover for the night before and the Bloody Mary gave me life. it even came with a cheese curd which, when in Wisconsin ya know? love that you dont have to ask for a beer chaser, it came with it! 

I ordered the carne asada hash. it was delicious but i was expecting a larger portion size. nonetheless, amazing. 

We came in right at opening and got pretty good service, the drinks and food initally took a little longer than expected to come out. Thats probably my only complaint but overall amazing spot, right across from.the Capitol. definitely try this place!

A group of 18 of us in Madison for my parents 60th wedding anniversary descended on Graze one Saturday at 5:05pm, just after opening.  They don't take reservations and I had called a few weeks earlier and they said they get pretty busy after 5:30 or 6pm and we should show up right at opening or face a possibly long wait.  There were already a number of tables seated when we showed up but the hostess was very helpful in getting our group of "cats" seated at 3 adjacent tables.  I think over half of our group got the Graze burger.  The bibimbap was also quite popular (three or four vegetarians). It was a beautiful afternoon, we were in a good mood and the service and ambience were fast and delightful.  Our table got the charcuterie platter with cheeses and meats.  Incredibly tasty but the portions were disappointingly small.  Everyone who had the bibimbap was very happy and agreed it was a sizable portion.  A consensus developed that the Graze burger had a combination of yummy fat mouthfeel and sweetness from the caramelized onions that needed balancing.  We didn't agree whether that should be a good blue cheese, sharp cheddar, Dijon mustard or jalapeños.  If I'm running the restaurant I'd put these as optional items on the signature Graze burger.  Over half our group didn't order alcohol; the bill with mandatory tip was just under $40 per person.

I recently was at Graze with a friend that is new to Madison. She's gluten free and vegetarian, and wow, did the staff pull out all the stops to help her find something that would meet both her dietary needs. They actually took the time to talk through preparations with her and offered to bring any questions to the chef if needed. That, my friends, is quality service. 

The bibimbap and aged cocktail I had weren't too bad either and the atmosphere was great. It's always fun to dine below those floor to ceiling windows with the capitol illuminated in the background.

I was here when I was celebrating a birthday. We ordered a delicious aged mac and cheese with panko breadcrumbs. Absolutely delicious. Great atmosphere. Open concept, glass tables, and superb lighting.

I've been in here many times since moving to Madison and it is probably my favorite spots to stop in for a late night burger and a beer.  They always have great beers on tap and their pub burger is served on an English muffin.. It's good.  They also have a buy one, get one happy hour that starts after 9pm on tapped beers.  Tough to beat that.  The bartenders I've had have always been friendly as well.

A great upscale restaurant in the heart of Madison! Our experience started when we were seated but a little cold due to the location of our table. We asked to be seated elsewhere and were promptly moved with a smile. Excellent service!

The first thing that struck me was how knowledgeable the waiter was on the food. He was able to describe every single dish beautifully, and it just made me hungrier and hungrier!

The boyfriend and I ordered plenty. The cheese curds were phenomenal with a side of buttermilk ranch. The pork belly buns were delicious. The french fries, especially the garlic aioli, were something from heaven. To end, my double smash burger was an absolute delight. So cheesy, and cooked perfectly although well done isn't my usual preference.

The other dishes we ordered, however, were not amazing. The Mac n cheese was ok, tasted a little sour, and the deviled eggs were nothing to write home about. Most disappointing was the graze burger my boyfriend ordered. The burger was sweet and didn't seem to match with all the conflicting flavors inside of it. It was almost like biting into a sweet reduction that was seasoned with the purpose of being savory and salty. Definitely not my favorite.

However, my whole experience was amazing, and I'll be sure to come back!

Coming from Toronto, I was clueless as to what gastronomical pleasures I would find in Madison. Graze was simply marvellous. The food was exquisite, fresh and portioned perfectly. The service was personable and attentive. The atmosphere was modern, simple and inviting. These are the types of gems I like to find when I travel. Highly recommend it to everyone who appreciates a quality food experience.

The tofu scramble was really, really good. Don't think it's going to be an actual scramble in any way. The tofu is merely folded into the sauce. But oh! that is a delicious sauce. I understand it changes seasonally, and were I closer, I'd get it every time it changed because I'm sure it'd be fantastic every time. The perfect dish to split after the cheese-fest that is the farmer's market across the way.

One of my favorite atmospheres in Madison, and in my opinion, the best cheese curds. Entrees can be hit or miss, so I usually like to go for a glass of wine & an appetizer. Pork buns are another must!

What can I say? I love this place. Such a bright and airy location. Fabulous view of the capital. The breakfast and brunch cocktails are superb. All of the breakfast items are delicious and well plated.

Graze is consistently one of the best places to get a meal in Madison. I've never had a bad meal here. They could stand to have a few more vegetarian options, but the ones they do have are all excellent. Whenever someone new to Madison asks me where to eat, Graze is always my first recommendation.
Always delicious and interesting. Great cocktails too. The cheesy polenta was miracle food.

I need to come here to eat but we came for the later happy hour that was from 9-11! I was excited to hear about this reverse happy hour because all beers were buy one get one. I was in the mood for a ginger beer cocktail and opted for the Open Sesame which included - Pimm's, Graze cucumber and ginger shochu, Canton, lime, ginger beer. The drink cost about $12 which was a little pricey but delicous! I will return to get food!

We were seated immediately for brunch by a dour host, but then quickly greeted by our seemingly-friendly waiter. We ordered uncomplicated meals i.e. eggs and toast. The appetizer and kid's meal arrived quickly, then things fell off the cliff. Twenty-five minutes after the appetizer arrived, our waiter never returned and was clearly avoiding eye contact. We ran out of water and had finished our salty cheese curds (which were really good). My husband finally located a pitcher of water. Our waiter watched him refill our glasses, yet continued to avoid us. After 40 mins, we finally flagged him down to enquire about the rest of our meals. He got quite defensive at our innocent, polite inquiry and waiter-splained to us that there is a space between appetizers and the meal (40 mins?!). Our meals arrived a few mins later and had clearly been sitting under a heat lamp. The eggs and toast were sub-par (below a Perkins standard) and served with a flavorless, dry, hockey puck of a hash brown/potato patty (hard to even call it a hash brown, really). My husband ordered chilaquiles and said they were at least good, but not really anything special or worth the 45 min wait. My son's mac and cheese was also good. I found it odd that kids' meals come with fries or mixed greens (do many four year olds eat mixed greens) but adult meals have the option of fresh fruit. I can't see any reason we would return given many better choices in the area. It's also telling that other restaurants had a wait at the same time and this restaurant did not; we should have taken that as a sign.

I loved their cheese curds. Served with their buttermilk aioli.

Deviled eggs were so good that i noted down all the ingredients to recreate it myself 

Shrimp salad was lackluster.

Service was really good - I sat at the bar

Love love love this restaurant and location! I've only been a handful of times but each time, I'm always impressed with the food and the service. The ambiance is amazing and I love the ever changing menu and the list of where the food comes from! Its a rarity these days to actually know where your food has come from and its fun to see the list of farmers and growers Graze buys food from. I recommend Graze to my friends and will continue to go.

This was one of the best meals I've had in Madison!  I went to school there so coming back 5 years later I went to some old favorites but decided to try somewhere new as well and was very impressed with it here. To start I had the seasonal punch which was peach flavored and absolutely delicious. My boyfriend and I split the graze burger and the mac and cheese with pulled pork, both of which were stellar! The atmosphere of the place and the view of the Capitol wasn't too shabby either!  Will definitely be making this place a must-go next time I'm in town.

I've ate at most of Madison's non-chain restaurants and this place is by far one of my favorites. Incredible atmosphere and right across from the capital with walking distance from many bars and theaters. The menu is very local yet has very diverse and unique entrees! Might be a bit of a wait to get seated but worth it!

It definitely is living by it's name (or I am not fancy enough.) We went for breakfast. The french toast was delicious but tiny. My spouse had a burger. He said it was good but the fries don't live up to what others have said. They are just fries. I did like the cheese curds, mostly the size of them. They are not too flavorful. If you like delicious cheese curds head to the old fashioned. We ran out of water and it wasn't replenished but we lived.

This is a decent place with local food, which was nice. I went for brunch and had the Eggs Benedict. It was tasty, but not amazing. My husband got a burger and salad. The food tasted fresh, the atmosphere was nice, and the service was fine. I was expecting more of a unique twist on the dishes though- everything was fairly basic. It was an overall satisfying but underwhelming experience.

My husband and I had our first farm to table experience at Graze and we were very pleased with our service and food thanks to our server Luke S. He was very helpful with the menu. His detailed description of the entrees was amazing! He's very passionate about his job. We will be back!

I ordered the carne asada hash. Overall it was a good meal, but the eggs were just a bit too funny for my liking. However, my friend ordered the same thing but thought the eggs were fine. The actual carne asada was great - very well seasoned and cooked perfectly. The location was great as well, very open with several windows.

Love this place! It does have a smaller menu, which I actually appreciate. Large menus with a million options can seem overwhelming. I love Graze's dedication to local, sustainable sources of food which keeps me coming back time after time, that, and of course the delicious meals and amazing customer service!

We went here before the end of 2013 and had a wonderful evening out. We hit up Graze for my significant others birthday and we were very glad with our choice. Having gone out on a Friday night, I knew there would be a wait but I also knew that Graze utilizes a website that will allow you to see where you are on the wait-list. We put our names in, and headed down the corner to grab a beer at a not-soo packed bar while we waited. When we saw that our names were soon on the list, we headed back to Graze. We were seated at one of the front tables that overlook the capital. I had a fantastic drink-I believe it was the "Keep your gin up" and the birthday boy had a take on a Moscow mule. I'm not a big meat eater, but I couldn't help but enjoy the bites of the Graze burger that were shared with me. The meat was seared perfectly on the burger and the onions were caramelized to perfection with just the right amount of sweetness to them. I ordered the bibimbap and didn't regret my decision there either. The crispy rice was amazing in contrast to the egg and the spicy sauce that it came with. We had been to Graze in the spring of 2013, and the trip we took at the end of 2013 completely surpassed the first visit in every way possible. The staff was prompt, courteous, and made great recommendations.

I came here on a weekday afternoon with my cousin and a friend for a light lunch. The floor to ceiling windows give you a great view of the capitol building and the cocktail list is lovely - we were able to try a few things we've never thought of before! The menu is limited but eclectic; great for small taster plates with few substantial options. 

Our waiter was patient and attentive and the vibe of the place is overall pretty great. 

If you're very hungry I'd save this place for later, but if you want to chill out and try their cheese plate, make a trip. I believe there's also a bakery here (?) or at least affiliated.

My boyfriend and I love this place. The cheese curds are the best in Madison, and every entree we have ever had has been phenomenal. The graze burger in particular is to die for and is totally worth the $21 price tag. We have never had a poor experience with service, though it usually is a long wait. We have resorted to having a late dinner (~9:30pm) just so that we can go there and walk right up to get a table.

If it were not for the pickles I would give it one star. 

On that note, the pickles are mostly very good, although the kimchi makes one think that the chef has never had kimchi before, as there was no spice to it. Every dish we ordered noticeably lacked boldness where it was called for: kimchi had no spice in it; the escabeche substituted cauliflower in place of the traditional jalapenos;bahn mi also lacked the traditional jalapenos and was made with an incredibly mundane ham, with a meager sprinkling of pickled vegetables. Spicy food makes me tear up but I'm not as scared of it as the chef.  

Both of our entrees had fries on the side, one order was overdone and the other underdone. Both orders of fries became soggy and lost their crispness five minutes out. Perhaps I am just spoiled by the divinity of Opa's fries.

Bibimbap burrito = 10/10. Would come back just to order this again. All ingredients fresh and locally grown. Service was on point. Ambience next to the Capitol was sweet too. Definitely check it out the next time you're in town!

One of my favorite restaurants in Wisconsin! Tonight was my second visit & it confirmed my love of Graze's great menu.  Our server was thoughtful & attentive. Dinner of mussels was delicious! Everyone had a very nice time...
The Graze burger is the best burger I've ever had! Everytime I went there I can't resist the burger. It is a nice place to enjoy the view of the capitol while dining.

I have been here twice now for lunch and have been blown away both times.  The first time I had the Pub Burger which was delivered on the homemade english muffin and despite the boring appearance.....I was blown away.  On initial inspection, I was so disappointed and felt doomed that this was going to be another wasted burger experience.........So wrong I was...the burger was cooked to perfection and the combination of flavors was like music in my mouth.  The english muffin brought this unique texture to an otherwise boring bun that would have been in its place.  The meat was cooked perfectly and the cheese melts in just the percent way.  Even the fries on the side were seasoned to my liking and the waitress  got me so hot sauce and ketchup and I was all smiles.

The second time I went I tried the Bibimbop with tofu and asked for it to be spicy......it was AWESOME....the rice was crispy, creating a texture amongst the smooshy egg and other ingredients.  The flavors burst in your mouth and made for an amazing lunch experience.  If you have not had it before....this is a must try.

Overall, the Graze delivers some amazing food....I could care less about the local, organic, or farm to table crap if the food is not good.  When the food is as amazing as Graze delivers....and on top of that it is locally sourced, it takes it to a whole other level.  This is a must try for any burger lover, and overall a great place to grab lunch.  I plan to give it a shot for dinner next time I am in town.

Excellent food and an amazing service. We ordered the cheese curds and it was marvelous. The double cheese burger was really good. I ordered fries with the burger and was disappointing, as it didn't taste fresh. Other than that, amazing experience.

I had the bibimbap, and I'll be honest, I really didn't like it. I didn't like that the rice was formed into a cubed and then pan fried. I preferred the traditional method of bibimbap. I also had the sweet potato soup which was, meh, ok-ish I guess. The menu didn't have much in it. Overall I do like the customer service, the cleanliness of the place, and the view right by the capital building.

I came with a party of 3 on a weekday at noon and we were seated right away. I had a coffee, a cheeseburger with bacon and cheddar on sesame brioche, and a side of deep-fried cheese curds. I liked that they offered them as a side, since not everywhere else did (otherwise, I was ready to commit to eating an order of deep-fried cheese curds as lunch). I ordered my burger medium-rare, and I know I probably should have just said rare, but it came more on the medium to well-done side (brown in the middle, not pink). I also wasn't impressed with the sesame brioche bun. If you have ever made brioche, you know how rich and buttery and delicious it is. This was a little dry. Our waiter was very friendly and let me know when ordering that there was some other type of brioche bun available (poppyseed? Something like that). The space was nice and reminded me of Isabel's in Portland.

I went here the first time because I was told it is now the only place one can buy etoile's croissants. Ahh how I miss the only bakery counter. Buying croissants to go there is possible but awkward (and not cheap of course).

I finally went there for dinner a few nights ago with two friends that go there regularly and love it. We had two toddlers with us (we ate very early so it wasn't too crazy yet) and the staff was very gracious about their craziness.

I had the risotto, which was excellent but I still wonder why all nice restaurants feel the need to douse dishes in truffle oil. We also tried the pickles and the banh mi. Both were good but did not knock my socks off. I would happily go again (perhaps some night when I have a babysitter though)

Food was wonderful and had many vegan options.  

FYI There are two menus- one of which indicating what food can be modified to be Gluten Free, Vegan, Vegetarian, etc.
The food is excellent and so is the service. The restaurant is very chic and you couldn't ask for a better location. Highly recommend this place.

First experience here was during Ironman 2013. Yesterday I completed Ironman 70.3 in this great city. My amazing fiancé & I went here for lunch today. He was there for Sunday brunch while I was sweating it out on the bike portion of the Tri. 

I indulged in a killer Bloody Mary - their homemade mix is not to be missed. Tito's vodka. 

The Hooks grilled cheese was worth the carb & calorie splurge. Mustard grain, local tomatoes & 3 different Hooks cheese. 

What a treat for our last meal before we head back to DC ...where it's a headache a minute there. Thank you Graze.

Vegetarians Beware!  
Went to Graze for dinner and came home hungry because I'd rather not cobble a meal together out of sides.  My husband got the mac and cheese, because he is apparently 11 years old... or because it is the only vegetarian meal option.  It's certainly sized for an 11 year old.  I had a mixed vegetable salad that was approximately four little carrots and a fried hash brown drizzled in oil.  It was infuriating that this paltry excuse for a salad cost more than a companion's beefy burger and fries!

And as far as the ambiance goes: Graze feels nothing like New York or Chicago, as one reviewer wrote.  But then again, I suppose it does have the "je ne sais quoi" of the Au Bon Pains at LaGuardia or O'Hare.  It features the same deafening, echoey acoustics, high prices, and food court seating... but at least they have decent vegetarian options.
Cheese Curds are incredible, Service is great, collard greens were delish and the ambiance was open and fresh. Biscuits were dry and Mac'n'cheese was ok (a little too 'American Cheese' tasting).

I came here for dinner on a Friday night (first mistake). The wait was atrocious. We waited for over an hour and a half (second mistake). I think this is why I don't remember much of my experience. From what I can remember they had bomb cocktails! I do not remember how the food was. I know I got the ever-popular mac n' cheese. I want to say it was just alright since I don't remember - probably meaning: It was just alright. 

Looking at the menu right now and props to Graze for their unique dishes and combinations and of course, all locally grown ingredients.

COST:
$2.50 (Coffee)
$10~ (Bibimbap Burrito)

After walking through a blizzard, literally anything we eat here would've been awesome. The friendliest people I've seen in Madison for sure. I was picking between their bibimbap burrito or breakfast sandwich and I was advised by the server to go for the burrito... and she was god damn right!

It's so surprising to me how a very clearly American looking place has such a fantastic brunch special. It was so delicious I wish had gone back for it. The flavors were exotic and the small side of kimchi was amazing. There was some special spicy sauce that came with it. It definitely had some kick to it and was on the sweet side as well, just perfect.

Last but not the least, let's talk about the coffee. They brewed and served Kickapoo Coffee's Winter Solstice which I'm still trying to find and buy online. It's the most delicious coffee I've ever had with hints of chocolate and caramel. It was awesome!

I look forward to a Madison return trip over the summer and I'll roll through Graze again.

I will go back for the bone marrow alone. I like me some animal parts, especially when it's prepared so well. Overall, has the prices and ambience of a big city gastropub, which can be nice for a quick dinner date before a show. The food was excellent though. As long as they don't hire a chef who screws it all up, they'll definitely be getting more of my money in the future.

We were combing through reviews and suggestions on where to have Sunday Brunch in Madison. We finally decided to give Graze a go because someone in our party was familiar with Chef Tory. We were seated immediately by a pleasant hostess. It was a relatively small specialized menu (which makes sense for the type of place it was). One of guests had a few restrictions, which did make it a bit hard. The staff didn't really seem to want to work with her on that. We found that a bit surprising. We ordered the fried cheese curds, the french toast sticks, beet salad, beet veggie burger, and bacon & eggs. The cheese curds were absolutely delicious and perfectly prepared. The french toast sticks were really disappointing. We expected something moist and tasty, instead were met with dry, bland, expensive for what they were (3 sticks). I would not recommend anyone get them, perhaps opt for the sticky bun. The veggie burger was good, but I was surprised they used American cheese to top it off. It really cheapens the whole thing. The bacon was severely undercooked, I was shocked. In the restaurant's defense, the person who ordered it didn't want to send it back, so they didn't have a chance to rectify it. The beet salad was good, albeit expensive again for the size. I feel like a goat cheese would've complemented it better than the Greek yogurt, but it's not my restaurant. We weren't overly impressed with the server, which kind of rounds out this whole experience with two stars. Maybe I'd consider it a three, but not sure I'd be going back anytime soon to try again. Oh, the view with the large windows and capitol right behind it make for an awesome ambiance!

Vodka battered cheese curds are a must try. And maybe you want to compare who's got better cheese curds in town. The pork buns are great. Beet burger is delicious. Biscuits and gravy for brunch is my fave. It's a big portion so you can share with four ppl. Waffles and pancakes are hard to miss. Chicken and waffle was okay. The burgers they offer are delicious. It's great knowing the food you eat is made from local ingredients.

ok... I have been here 4 times now. So I feel I can write an honest review. 

Atmosphere- cool
Menu concept- cool
Menu execution- blah.
Service- BAD 

The restaurant industry is all about consistency... graze lacks this quality!  It was good the first time, but after that it has been bad. Most of all (like other reviewers) the service is sub par. Good thing you are on the square otherwise I don't think you would be around much longer.

I was introduced to Graze through their Magic Coffee that they sell during the summer at the farmer's market. I was hooked when i went in for drinks and dinner with a friend. I love the idea of locally-sourced food and it was delicious! Their cocktail menu is also wonderful and the view of the Capital building can't be beat.

I went here on a sunny spring day with my wife for lunch.  It has a cool modern atmosphere with direct views of the capitol from almost any seat.  The burger I had was good, but very messy.  I think the bun could have been slightly bigger.  I like the huge ceilings inside.  Overall a good option on the square that I will try again.  I think happy hour here could be a good idea especially with summer on the way and their big tap beer selection.

I don't quite get the hype around this place. Whenever someone comes from out of town, I feel like this is the place that gets recommended the most. If you come on a Friday or Saturday, the wait usually hovers around an hour or so depending on the size of your group. I've had multiple dishes on both their dinner and brunch menus and while they do use fresh local ingredients, the actual entrees are a mixed bag. The burger is probably the most disappointing entree on their menu as it comes out a lot smaller than you expect it to be and is not always cooked to the doneness that you asked for. I feel pretty similarly about their steak entree but it seems like they've taken it off their menu. I do like their chicken and waffles for brunch, particularly because it comes with the thinner American waffle which I always enjoy more than the standard Belgian waffle. I also maintain that their vodka battered cheese curds are the best I've had in Madison, though the portion size has been steadily shrinking over the past few years. I may stop in for a cheese curd fix from time to time but I won't be coming back for a full meal anytime soon.

My wife had the Eggs Benedict, which not only looks superb, but she said it was excellent.
My Bacon Cheeseburger was great and presentation was spot on.  It was cooked perfectly.
We also ordered the Artisan Cheese tray with cherry compote, which was exceptional, but very small.
My wife ordered a Chai and stated it was really good, but it was around $4 for a small Chai, so she thought it was overpriced.
I'd give Graze 4 Stars, but it is a bit overpriced for the area and our waitress was abysmal.  She only came to the table three times total and we didn't feel important.  Great presentation, horrible service.

Great service, sat at bar and had beer went to order beet and walnut burger and was told that's only available for lunch very disappointed!! Had the veggie burger was ok, the English muffin made it very dry, better if was on another kind of bread.

It seems that there is a constellation of very, very good restaurants surrounding the Capitol.  One in that constellation is Graze.

We visited early evening, nearly opening the place.  The setting is open, airy, convivial, relaxed, effervescent.  

The service was attentive, our server very knowledgeable about preparations and willing to step up and make actual recommendations.

Our meal included Roasted Fall Squash, Artesian (a local farm) Trout, a burger and an apple crisp.

The Roasted Fall Squash came with goat cheese.  It almost seemed designed by some 'foodologist', offering and exploring subtle complimentary tastes.  Fresh, seasonal.

The Roasted Artesian Trout came with celery root purée, delicata squash, lemon browned butter, and rye croutons.  Generous and a wonderful medley of tastes. 

The burger was good, it being hard to stretch limits on that, but the accompanying fries got my partner's comment of 'best fries ever!'

The menu offers choices for diners with a view of their diet.  For us, that meant seeing gluten free choices.

The apple crisp was made gluten-free at our request.   Very tasty, our waitress explaining for the gluten free it just different components to the crumble, recommending it.  Ice cream was on the side per our request--delicious!

So, out of this world good!  Actually, out of this world great!

I was at Graze on a Saturday afternoon (off-time, around 4pm) for the cheese curd crawl. I was told that most of the crawl people were simply ordering from the bar, so I did that. I mentioned that I was with a group of 10, and the bartender said that he'd recommend a basket of cheese curds, as it would be enough for everyone to try a curd or two. I ordered and paid (the basket didn't get the crawl discount that the smaller order would have, but that was fine with me at the time). I then waited for 30 minutes, during which time people came, got cheese curds, and left. I went to the bartender again and asked if he had a time estimate, to which he shrugged and said "I have no idea, soon?". I then went to a server and asked, and she told me to ask the bartender about it. At this point it had been about 40 minutes since I had ordered. The server talked to the bartender, and the bartender called out to me over the bar and said that it was "miscommunication because I had moved". I had moved about 10 feet from where I was initially standing to avoid crowding people eating at the tables at Graze, and I was still making occasional eye contact with the bartender and completely within view of him for the duration of the wait. When we finally got the "basket" of cheese curds, it was a large basket with only 7 curds in it. I was not offered an apology or comp for this mess. 

I am extremely disappointed in Graze, which markets itself as an upscale "experience". The only "experience" I got from Graze was one filled with rude, inconsiderate service. The cheese curds were delicious - but were 7 curds worth ~$8, a 45 minute wait, and being blamed for an employee's lack of attention? I don't think so, and neither do the other members of my group, who will not be returning to a place with such awful service.

Good solid food in a nice atmosphere. Everything is clean.  The food is fresh and delicious. The bar selection is very nice. Good for people watching and a view of the Capital. We have had dinner and brunch here and it is clearly a popular place.

Great upscale dining restaurant in Capitol square! I really loved the decor and service of this place. The staff were extremely courteous and friendly. 

This is actually the first place I ever tried cheese curds at in all of Madison, and I thoroughly enjoyed them! I got the chicken and waffles which was also fantastic! For the price point, it's well worth the meal. 

I'd recommend this place if you're looking for a nicer restaurant within walking distance to State Street or just in the Capitol area!

I wished the food was better (sigh). 
I also wished that cocktails were better. 

And, those pastries prepared for the Saturday farmer's market .... pretty bad. I used to like then Cafe Soleil pastries, but the apple croissant and chocolate croissant I had recently were just mess. If they haven't figured out already, their competitions are kickin' their butt.

I've been to Graze several times now & seem to have made it a habit to come for special occasions including my own birthday. The view of the capitol building with the floor to ceiling windows makes for a great happy hour spot, not to mention their amazing craft cocktails. I have only sat down to eat one time but when I did - I felt that our server was very attentive & gave us a great experience.

Used to love this place.  The summer drink menu is disappointing and the service last time was lacking.  We went there for happy hour, and found out that we could only use our chip (Buy 1, Get 1 tap beers/wine) before 6 p.m.   It would have been nice if someone would have told us that, esp. since we went there only for happy hour.  This used to be the place to go for us (as a young mod place) with drinks that were $8-12 and well worth it.  After our last trip there, I am not sure we will be back.  Two drinks and an appetizer and our bill was nearly $40.  We are happy to pay that if the service is good and the menu has good selections.  This place is going to go under if they don't fix something.

We were drawn to Graze for how consistently busy it was every time we walked by. Went for Saturday night dinner, no reservation but were able to sit at the bar. Wine list was ok, the beer my bf ordered was average. Started out with cheese curds, yum! As a MN girl that's had a few cheese curds, they were divine. Next, we devoured the Wedge salad. Amazing!! We decided to try the Graze burger and see what all the Rachael Ray hype was about. Now, I love expensive food so a $21 burger was intriguing to me... Well... It was good.. But we had just stopped at Culvers the night before and really enjoyed the butter burger... Is it wrong if we think they are comparable?

 Overall, great experience and would recommend for a fun night out. Skip the Graze burger and order one of the other delicious options, like the Bun which sounded amazing.

For me, the menu is a bit limited but the food always tastes good when I go. I usually get better service from tables than the bar, so I'd head there if I go. Expect to pay a pretty penny, but you'll get good local food and interesting drinks, if you like to drink a bit.
Very nice Sunday brunch. Varied menu. Tasty food.  Adjacent to the Capitol Building.  Not as crowded as some of the other brunch places ( with food just as good).

Delicious!  Their food is absolutely amazing and out of this world.  I have never been disappointed with a drink or menu item.  They also have a lot of fun 5-course specialty dinners.  The wait can be long at times, but they will call your cell phone when your table is ready.  Brunch is my favorite!  They may have the best Bloody Mary in town!

In a word, overrated. However, I went during Restaurant Week, so I'd like to give them the benefit of the doubt.

The wait was short, thankfully, as it was crowded and uncomfortable both at the bar and entryway. My date and I were seated at a very tiny table, but you can't argue with the view. I could've done without the wait staff frequently bumping into us. And the heat. Summer in Wisconsin gets warm, especially through all glass walls.

The drinks came quickly, thankfully. The waiter seemed quite stressed and worked fast without much sweet talk, but again, Restaurant Week. We placed our orders and were surprised to receive a basket of popcorn - which actually looked stale and gross - that we hadn't ordered. Figuring this was complimentary, we were about to take bites, until another waiter came running over asking if we had ordered it, and if we had eaten from it already. Turns out it was for another table. Somewhat disgustingly, he took it from us and re-served it to the correct table.

The courses were well done and timed well. The fish was cooked to perfection. The appetizer was so-so. Dessert was delicious. Ordering one final drink at the end of the meal, however, took forever to get to us (nothing fancy, just beer on tap).

The idea is wonderful with the local produce and meat, but the ambiance, noise, and price just weren't worth it to me. Would I give Graze a second shot? Probably, but not during restaurant week, and not on a weekend evening.

Definitely a great place, but I couldn't get over thinking it was over rated and over priced. The food is fresh and tastes good, but the portions were small and I felt they were quite varied between the dishes. 

If you get really excited about "farm-to-table" you might give them an additional star, but there are tons of restaurants in Madison serving farm fresh/responsible ingredients without going on and on (and on) about it every chance they get.

Would I come back? Sure, but not until I eat at a lot of other places first.

Great atmosphere, right across from the capitol with floor to ceiling windows. A more casual mirror image of its sister restaurant next door. I had the Graze burger, which was decent. The cheese curds were good, huge chunks of fried cheese. I also had some kind of pecan pie, which was okay, but really not great.

Beautiful view if youre new to Madison, gazing at the Capiral building at sunset while enjoying PEI mussels! The Bibimap was fun and different, lots of kimchi but a touch too spicy, the beet salad was perfect. They also have a good selection of wine and beers. I may return before i leave.

My boyfriend and I originally planned to go to the old fashioned. We must have been struck with bad luck today because we drove two hours to dine there! We were so disappointed! We found graze after walking around and trying to get into other burger joints. Those of course were too packed. We then went to graze and were expecting to get burgers, but they only offered the brunch menu. So we weren't really crazy about any of the options. However, we were starving and did not want to want in line at another busy restaurant. We heard their cheese curds were quite a hit so we of course had to try them. I'll admit it they were perfection. The cheese was melty and gooey and so so delicious. My boyfriend ordered the pub burger for his main course and I ordered the madame croque. My boyfriend ordered his burger medium and got his medium well. He did not understand why they put it on an english muffin because it was just plain soggy. My meal was pretty good but nothing worth raving about. The highlight was definitely the cheese curds. I was not into the atmosphere at all and the service was mediocre.

I tried the graze burger there. It is quite good, though a little bit greasy. The view is perfect and nice beer choice. And highly recommend cheese curd. They have the right souce with it. But remember to reserve a seat in ahead, otherwise too long a line during dinner time.

The food is excellent by bar food standards and they have some unique items. Most people would never think to order popcorn as an appetizer, but they make theirs with truffle oil and it's incredible! They also have great sandwiches, including one made with a duck liver pate that is very good if you like pate. The environment is very sheik. My one minor complaint is that the seating isn't very comfortable, but I still highly recommend checking this place out.

I was in town for business arriving to -27 degree weather. I'm happy to say the welcome was much warmer. I loved this place! The food was great (the soup could be served a bit warmer). This Florida girl won't be back in January (ever) but if I will absolutely return at any another time.

My go to spot for brunch

Graze has won me over.  My first couple visits were less than memorable - I could see the potential in the menu, but the execution left something to be desired.  But over the past year, the consistency kitchen and the service has improved considerably and Graze has been coronated as The Emperor of Madison Brunch until further notice.  

After a recent trip to the Madison Farmer's Market, my wife and I decide the dodge the rain drops and grab some morning vittles (and libations).  There are a thirty minute wait for a table, so we decided to set up camp at the bar.  The bartenders promptly welcomed us and took our drink order.   I tried the Retox (Cachaça, Maple Syrup, lemon juice, cayenne) and my better half went with the Bloody Mary.  At first I was neutral on the Retox, but it eventually won my over as the Cachaça (a liquor made from fermented sugarcane juice) cleared the fog from a soggy slog around the square.  The Bloody Mary was a little heavy on the horseradish for my taste, but my dining companion was very impressed.

As for the culinary component, I elected to try something new and ordered the Chicken-Fred steak.  Instead of the usual cream-based sauce, this version had a excellent brown sauce with a hint of sage which complimented the steak, which was top notch, it had a nice crunch, but not greasy.  The rest of te dish was satisfying as well.  Some lightly dressed grape tomatoes, crispy hash browns and two eggs easy over that were perfectly executed.    Portion size was just right - I cleaned my plate and felt satiated, but not bloated.  We finished off our brunch date with an order of the beignets, and their pillowy goodness was the perfect finish to an excellent meal.

While the meal was a bit on the pricey side for brunch ($55 for two drinks, two entrees and a dessert), we both felt the value of the meal exceeded the price.

There have been some complaints about the service at Graze, but the bar staff was courteous and attentive during our meal.  Despite a full house in a relatively open space, the noise level was not too bad - it was easy to carry on a conversation.

I also appreciate how Graze uses locally sourced products from area farms to create its menu.  As long as they can continue to effective execute the vision of Chef Tory Miller, they will continue to be my go-to option for brunch.

I'm surprised that Graze doesn't have higher ratings! I loved that the ambiance was casual but at the same time slightly up-scale (perhaps it was just the dimly lit dining area) - but I could definitely see myself there unwinding after a long work week with a drink and a burger and not feel awkward dressed in business casual. 

I have to say that I was very impressed by the menu and the whole concept of "eating local" - or maybe it's just because I am a Californian girl and I am impressed by anything Mid-Western that reminds me of the golden state (I really do love Wisconsin though, I promise!) 

Anyway...I'm not usually a big fan of cheese, but I found the cheese curds quite delicious, and not bland as other reviewers may have mentioned.  But I guess I've never had fried cheese curds before Graze, so I can't really compare. I'm just really glad that these ones were fried and did not squeak against my teeth. 

Besides the fried cheese curds, I also tried the veggie Pub Burger. The patty was a little dry for my taste and kept crumbling as I tried to eat it with a fork and knife, but otherwise it was a good effort. I have to say that my favorite part of the meal was the fries. Nicely seasoned, and deep-fried to perfection. Yum! :9

Had the $21 burger which was a bit greasy and lacking in flavor.  Fries were not bad but too salty.  The Korean nachos I was expecting to be good, but had probably an ounce of beef with the rest comprised of cheese and a gochujang sauce. We ended up leaving more than half on the plate. Also had the pork belly baos where I was treated to the pleasant texture of cartilage in the pork. 

Really nice atmosphere but the chef is not doing the locally-sourced produce any favors with these menu items.

I love that Graze is dedicated to local producers. Everything on the menu is local and hence, super fresh. 

I had quite a difficult time picking out my brunch - I was debating between the tofu scrambler and the sausage. The idea of tofu and eggs sounds exciting but the spice factor scared me away to the safer choice. The sunny side up eggs were done perfectly - running smoothly into my potatoes and rye toast. The sausage was a soft texture and a true sausage flavor without any spices or cheeses stealing its thunder. 

My friends had the ramen, eggs benedict, biscuits and gravy - all a great choice and equally delicious. I always want to come to a breakfast place like this - a little risky and creative yet true to traditional brunch and cares for local farms. Yay, Graze! Can't wait to eat you for dinner!
Best cheese curds and Mac & Cheese in Madison! Great experience with the waiters, and the atmosphere is nice too. The burgers might need a little work though.
The quality of service and food is satisfactory but the quantity of the food is not as good. Still felt hungry after I finished a plate.

My favorite place in Madison. I really enjoy taking out of town family members here because of their local food items and the beautiful view of the capital. Every time that I come for breakfast, I always order the special which is usually a scramble and it's always amazing.

I visited Madison, WI for only 3 days and I visited Graze 3 times.  It was so fantastic we kept finding a reason to go back.  Great drinks! Great food! Fantastic and interesting cheese selection (some amazing WI truffle goat cheese).  Just a great restaurant that is bright and beautiful with delicious food made from local ingredients.

I am loving Madison more and more. The locals vacate downtown after work and the parking is free after 6, how bucolic. I don't think I have parked more then 1/2 a block away from anywhere I wanted to eat.
A short stroll past the lone homeless man and I was at Graze. It shares the entrance with L'etoile which is the upscale sister restaurant.
I like the relaxed casual aura of Graze. All the glass makes eating inside feel outside or you can also opt to eat out side. I luckily picked a spot at the bartenders station and watched all the interesting cocktails being crafted.
So inital bummer there was no beer flight to taste their selection of on tap ales but YEA!! they let me taste everything. The sour is really sour; some of the others are very light. I went with the Scotch Ale, yum!
I started with the Pork bun... I was expecting a slider but got an abbreviated serving of crisp pork in a chinese style bun... little disappointed, my expectations exceeded reality. It was good but I would not get it again. The mixed green salad was good and standard.
Next I ordered a Wolverine and learned I am not a big fan of ginger syrup; I really wanted a margarita.
I finished with the Graze burger - delicious. The bottom bun is really just a sponge for all the juices coming oozing out of the burger. I suggest immediately flipping it over because the bottom bun is not very structurally sound once it has soaked up all the love from the burger. I really wanted to have the duck fat bun instead of the brioche. The fries were good.
Overall a wonderful meal with a little company from the bartenders.
I would have gotten dessert but there was nothing chocolate to my liking. Need to at least have one thing chocolate.
Great place and I like the farm to table concept. The menu is good and I want to go back for the chicken and waffles of the smash burger to get the duck fat bun. The steak read to be yummie but pricey.
One of our "go to" places when we come to Madison. The dishes are all very creative, tasty and generous. Don't miss it!

Great bar and dining area. Outdoor seating is awesome (available during the months with nice weather in Wisconsin). Food quality is way up there, when I lived in Madison and wanted to take my wife somewhere for dinner, Graze was always in the running. 

Graze burger is up there as one of the best burger I've ever eaten. You must get an order of cheese curds for an appetizer, & if you enjoy oysters, like me, then you're going to want to also get an order. :)

Steak frites is melt in your mouth delicious. 

Those pork buns are a yummy way to start your meal.

I've also had the beet and walnut burger, the Wisconsin cheese board, kimchi deviled eggs, mac n' cheese. All good. 

Never left Graze unsatisfied, it is a must stop when I'm back in town for business.

Stopped in for a birthday drink and appetizer.   There was a 90 minute wait for a table so we decided to check out the bar.  We got 2 seats at the bar within 5 minutes with a great view of the capital.  We started off with some drinks and then cheese curds and the pretzel.  Delicious!  We decided to hang around and have some dinner.  Really quick service, great drinks (seasonal punch was yummy), and scrumptious eats.  Check it out!

This restaurant came highly recommended by training staff on my trip to WI.  I was disappointed.  I love burgers and was very excited about trying the Graze burger.  I was so underwhelmed!  The burger was $20+ and was so bland.  I added salt to it to make it palatable but I have had much better burgers at fast food restaurants.  My coworkers tried other dishes that were just ok as well.  They have a nice ambiance and drink selection but that's about it. The service was great and waitstaff was nice but save your money. :(

I've had good, and I have had bad.  The good, actually the best, were the Oysters.  Fresh, clean, chilled, and tastes like the ocean.  Having grown up on the ocean, I was shocked to eat oysters in Madison, WI that tasted like they had just been pulled out of the water.  I've had both burgers, and I think either one is ok.  The spendy burger, as I like to call it, just has WAY too much going on to really appreciate any one component.  I appreciate the ambition of this dish, but too much gets lost in the process.  The average burger is, well, it's average.  Far better burgers in other places around town.  The trout plate was simply amazing, and I was again stammered by it because I have been a fisherman for most of my life and trout have been my primary catch.  The bone marrow is something that you think might be gross, but once you've got it dressed up on the bread it all comes together well.  I'm not a person who easily deals with soft textures, but the marrow had me wanting more.  The cheese curds are hit or miss.  Some days, they are simply amazing.  Light, crispy and not overdone (I mean this in terms of cooking and size of curd), the first time I had these I knew they were the best I had eaten.  The pork entree, quite frankly, sucked when I ordered it.  I was shocked at how tough the ribs were, but the pulled pork was great.  The liver appetizer was good, and you'll probably love it if you're a liver person.  The fries are usually amazing.  Pork bun was good...I don't know what else one can say about a Pork bun.

I've eaten a couple of other items, but I can't remember enough about them to comment here.  That's not a dig on Graze, but I have found myself thinking that the biggest issue there is consistency.

Service has always been great when I have gone.  Alcohol selections are good as well.  I'll definitely be back because it's usually a good experience.  I've had some bad experiences, but I'm not going to hold those over Graze's head and get all uppity about it.  There are few restaurants in this world that are perfect.  Also, as much as people loved Soleil...I find the new location to be FAR better.  Ditto for L'Etoile.  Even though they just moved up the street, the ambiance and views are exponentially better.
Mac and cheese was amazing, and all of the employees were very very helpful and attentive!!!

the decor fits warmly with the ethos of graze rather well. the atmosphere is lively but intimate. the wine list is surprisingly well-curated and the cocktails look fetching enough.

- the deviled eggs are forgettable but the smoked paprika aioli? holy damn. 
- the gratin is a little confusing to consume at first but it's a lovely simple dish for the cold season.
- the mac-n-cheese (minus the pork) was simply delectable.
- the artesian rainbow trout was perfectly seared.
- the curry vinaigrette in the warm farro salad was tasty.



all in all, this place defines gastropub.

Be prepared to wait for a table for dinner.  Ended up eating at the bar.  Staff was prompt.  Mixed drinks were light on spirits, but still tasty.  The smash burger they offer is probably one of the best burgers I've ever had.  So much flavor that I can't begin to describe.  It was simply amazing.  Food was brought out so quick after ordering.  Great experience over all.

My new favorite restaurant in Madison, WI. 
I am all about eating local and this place blows any self proclaimed local feeding trough out of the water. The ambience of the place is incredible; very minimal yet intriguing and warm. When it gets dark the view of the capital is spectacular and a real gem. The service was great and the staff was formal enough and very modern. I didn't mind paying a bit more for my bill because the food was absolutely perfect and I appreciate them supporting local farms in Wisconsin--especially in this crazy drought. The craft cocktail menu makes it hard to have just one! Also, the local beers on tap really gives it a down home Wisconsin feel. The only complaint I have is if you have to wait, they call your phone when your table is ready. However, if you do not have service or do not hear it you may be out of luck. I've always been a fan of a buzzer but I suppose that technology may be a bit tacky for the feel they are going for. If you're looking for a modern, fresh and flawless meal be sure to visit Graze.

I actually only thought this place was ok for the prices. Maybe I'm used to NY food/service and it's not a fair comparison.

We were initially told that it would be a 15min wait so we took a walk and came back. We ended up having to wait 30min which is a horrific difference, but still something that bugged me since I was starving at the time. It also was frustrating since when we were being seated there were a few tables that were open, but just hadn't been cleared. I don't think the efficiency of this place is that great.

The food itself was decent. We ordered the pork belly bun as an appetizer which was pretty good but not the best pork bun I had ever had. what I think really wasn't worth is was the tofu my dad ordered. You think that for $20 of tofu you would get more than 4 slices! Or at least get the most delicious tofu you've ever tasted! That was not the case at all...
However, my mom ordered their burger (which was $19) and that one was pretty good and I would say worth the $19, so I guess you should just order carefully.

An overpriced, overly trendy excuse for a restaurant!  Who runs out of chicken?  Seriously?????  Ordered the noodle bowl since they ran out of chicken and that thing was a complete fail.  It had no flavor unless you count old pork/pork belly smell and taste as flavor.  I do not!  It was supposed to come with a soft-poached egg in it- no egg to be found.  It really wouldn't have made the dish palatable regardless!  Should have just eaten at Tipsy Cow for lunch instead of only stopping for a drink while waiting for Graze to seat us.  And get some Moscow Mule mugs for Pete's sake!
Fantastic restaurant. Food quality, presentation and creativity was amazing. Staff was very friendly.

Stop here to try their Magic coffee after hearing great reviews. I'm so disappointed after a couple of sips my coffee was gone!! Why?? Too much ice not enough coffee for the price. Other wise coffee was great.

Overall, the place was okay. Its a beautiful location in the heart of downtown. The view is great and the lighting is wonderful. 

I had the Korean bbq sandwich, which was spicy and pretty delicious. The side salad though was underdressed and overall a little "eh". 

My boyfriend had the pub burger, which once again was okay. It was fairly nice burger, but nothing to write home about. 

Our experience is an overwhelming meh. There are no true complaints, I was just let down by the hype associated with this place.

One of my favorite places to go to brunch! The atmosphere is wonderful because the big window allows you to get a great view of the Capitol and makes the place so vibrant and bright. 

I usually go for brunch and start off with the beignets, which are fluffy and have the right consistency (essential for good beignets). I got the bibimbap breakfast burrito and as a Korean, I definitely approve of Graze's twist on this traditional Korean dish. The rice has a bit of spice, the meat inside is marinated very well, and the vegetables inside balance it out. The burrito is also huge so you could definitely share it or keep some leftovers to eat later. I would also recommend getting their pancakes with fruit because they use whatever fruit is in season and the pancakes are light and just sweet enough. Check this place out for brunch if you're ever hungry strolling down the farmers market or downtown on the weekends!

I think this place is way over-hyped for what it offers. The Pros: The atmosphere is memorable, and the views of the capitol at night are beautiful. Their brunch selection is great, especially during the Farmer's Market, if you are content to wait in line. The Cons: Their bread and butter is dinner, and I feel that it leaves a lot to be desired. The menu is sporadic and lacks a consistent theme. I have been there a few times over the years, but I don't remember most of the things I have eaten because they were just average (as a foodie, I remember every detail of the many amazing meals I have had). A lot of the dinner items are basically lunch items with an upcharge, and I think the prices are excessive for the quality of the food. The drinks have also been hit-or-miss.
Food was fantastic!! The wait staff was very helpful in explaining items and friendly. A little loud but it was pretty crowded. Tried emu for the first time!!
